column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Paint a City Skyline in Watercolor
#Text=A city skyline is exciting to see and fun to paint .
#Text=This project focuses on using geometric shapes , including the square , rectangle , triangle , and to a lesser degree , the circle rather than following the laws of perspective .
#Text=The result is a stylized , make-believe view of a city rather than a realistic one .
#Text=Artists of any skill level can have a good time exploring the city and build confidence by doing what can often be thought of as a difficult subject .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Preparing and Sketching
#Text=Gather your supplies and find a well-lit , quiet place to work .
#Text=Try to locate yourself where you can work undisturbed over a period of hours or even a day or two .
#Text=Find an array of brushes including flats in a variety of widths .
#Text=Get a water vessel , tissues , and a pencil with an eraser .
#Text=Have a piece of household sponge cut very small to use to stamp out windows .
#Text=Use masking fluid and a small , flat brush to help you when creating the windows as well .
#Text=A white wax crayon can be substituted .
#Text=Either will resist the paint .
#Text=Draw out the rooftops of all your buildings first .
#Text=Open an 11 ” X 14 ” pad of 140 lb . watercolor paper .
#Text=Hold the paper in either orientation .
#Text=Draw , freehand , a line of building roofs in pencil all across the paper , near the top .
#Text=Keep it simple - just draw geometric shapes side by side with lots of variety in heights .
#Text=Include many deep dips for interest .
#Text=Draw another line a little up from the bottom edge of the paper to indicate where the buildings start from at the bottom .
#Text=Then draw lines down from the rooftops of the buildings ending at this line to sketch out the whole building .
#Text=Sketch out center(s) of interest .
#Text=On this sidewalk or street area , sketch a fountain or other thing that you might find in a real city .
#Text=A figure or two , dog walkers , a memorial statue or sculpture , a small tree surrounded by a decorative fence , a table and chairs at a sidewalk café , a news stand , etc.
#Text=Try not to place a feature in the dead center of your picture .
#Text=Mask out an area for your feature object(s) ( fountain , statue . )
#Text=Use masking fluid and a brush to scribble out a spot for these features and protect it from the paint .
#Text=Indicate windows one of two ways .
#Text=Before painting , mask out some tiny windows .
#Text=Use a small , flat brush and masking fluid .
#Text=Or , use a light-colored crayon ( white , yellow , etc. ) and draw short strokes for windows .
#Text=They can be randomly placed or grouped in creative ways .
#Text=Painting
#Text=Prepare your brush .
#Text=Pick up a 1 ” flat brush and load it with any color of well diluted paint , working from a puddle of color that you made on your palette .
#Text=Do this by diluting any color with water .
#Text=Do n't scrimp , really fill your brush .
#Text=Paint a layer of colored stripes for the buildings .
#Text=Start at the top of one of the buildings and make a continuous stroke ending it at the line at the bottom of the page .
#Text=Paint a number of lines in one color , repeating this for every outline of each building you made .
#Text=Change colors for different buildings if you 'd like .
#Text=Continue until you have a multi-colored layer of various width stripes over the entire paper .
#Text=Allow this to dry .
#Text=A hairdryer can help with drying the page faster .
#Text=If you want to put two wet lines of color next to each other , leave a tiny sliver of dry paper between them .
#Text=If colors merge , go along with it , as a classic watercolor “ happy accident . ”
#Text=Add another layer of colored stripes to add detail to your painting .
#Text=Choose a ½ ” flat brush and load it with any color .
#Text=Do this on the now-dry painting to preserve the freshness of colors you already put down .
#Text=Paint doorways , more windows , edgings and frames along the tops of some of the windows and buildings , etc.
#Text=Turn the brush sideways and use it to stamp texture on one or two of the buildings .
#Text=Add any amount of small details you 'd like until you are satisfied that your scene is interesting and varied .
#Text=Allow this to dry .
#Text=Paint the foreground .
#Text=Unmask the area you preserved .
#Text=Draw and paint the object(s) that you chose for visual interest .
#Text=Paint the streets , the sidewalks , people , cars , or any other thing you 'd find in a real city that you sketched out .
#Text=Allow the piece to dry thoroughly and touch up areas that need punching up .
#Text=Hang the picture to view over time .
#Text=It might inspire you to paint another street scene .
#Text=We get new ideas from looking at what we have created .
#Text=We picture things we would like to change or add .
#Text=This is what keeps us painting and creating .
#Text=Also , be aware that in your travels , you will see city views with new eyes .
#Text=Art makes your powers of observation keener and you will find a greater appreciation and beauty in what was once considered the mundane and ordinary .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Play around with your paints prior to starting any project .
#Text=Test color mixtures and above all , aim to achieve the correct consistency of paint .
#Text=This one thing is all important in doing successful watercolors .
#Text=Put a few strokes of clear water onto your palette .
#Text=Add pure , undiluted paint gradually .
#Text=Test the paint on scrap paper often .
#Text=It should be thick enough to clearly show the color , but transparent enough to allow the white paper to shine through .
#Text=Avoid , at all costs , working with your paint too dense .
#Text=A play of light is what makes watercolor successful .
#Text=Use only good , strong watercolor paper ( student grade if fine initially ) to support the paint .
#Text=Respect the white of the paper - allow it to do its work by not overwhelming it .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=A set of paints , either a tin of eight ( or more ) or dry pads of color
#Text=Several brushes , including flats in a variety of widths
#Text=Water vessel
#Text=Tissues
#Text=A pencil with an eraser
#Text=Small piece of sponge for the windows
#Text=Masking fluid/light colored crayon
#Text=Watercolor paper
